## Definition of Liquid Types

We will now introduce the notion of liquid types to our type system. Type do now depend on a context.

```{theorem,name="mono types (with liquid types)"}
\begin{letIn}
$\Gamma:\mathcal{V}\nrightarrow\{\mathit{Bool},\mathit{Int}\}$ for the algebraic types $\mathit{Bool}=\mathit{True}|\mathit{False}$ and $\mathit{Int}=0|1|-1|2|-2|\dots$.
\end{letIn}
We say
$$
\begin{aligned}
T \text{ is a }\mathit{mono} \ \mathit{type} \text{ in the context of } \Gamma:\Leftrightarrow
       \ & T \text{ is a type variable}\\
  \lor \ & T \text{ is a type application in the context of }\Gamma\\
  \lor \ & T \text{ is a algebraic type in the context of }\Gamma\\
  \lor \ & T \text{ is a product type in the context of }\Gamma\\
  \lor \ & T \text{ is a function type in the context of }\Gamma\\
  \lor \ & T \text{ is a liquid type in the context of }\Gamma\\
T \text{ is a }\mathit{poly} \ \mathit{type} :\Leftrightarrow
       \ & T = \forall a.T'\\
         & \text{ where } T' \text{ is a mono type or poly type and } a \text{ is a symbol}\\
  T \text{ is a }\mathit{type} :\Leftrightarrow 
       \ & T \text{ is a mono type} \ \lor \ T \text{ is a poly type}.
\end{aligned}
$$
using the following predicate
$$
\begin{aligned}
T \text{ is a }\mathit{liquid} \ \mathit{type} \text{ in the context } \Gamma:\Leftrightarrow
       \ & T = {v:Int|f} where $v$ is a symbol and f is a predicate contaning 
  \lor \ & T = {v:Bool|f} where $v$ is a bool
\end{aligned}
$$
```
